Fig 9 Al-incorporation into Li7La3Zr2O12 solid electrolyte keeping stabilized cubic phase for all-solid-state Li batteries Changbin Im a Dongwon Park a Hosung Kim d Jaeyoung Lee a b c ⁎ a Chemical Energy Storage and Transformation Center (CHESS), Research Institute for Solar and Sustainable Energies (RISE), Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology (GIST), Gwangju 500–712, South Korea Chemical Energy Storage and Transformation Center (CHESS) Research Institute for Solar and Sustainable Energies (RISE) Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology (GIST) Gwangju 500–712 South Korea b Ertl Center for Electrochemistry and Catalysis, GIST Research Institute, GIST, Gwangju 500–712, South Korea Ertl Center for Electrochemistry and Catalysis, GIST Research Institute, GIST, Gwangju 500–712 South Korea c Electrochemical Reaction and Technology Laboratory, School of Earth Sciences and Environmental Engineering, GIST, Gwangju 500–712, South Korea Electrochemical Reaction and Technology Laboratory School of Earth Sciences and Environmental Engineering, GIST, Gwangju 500–712 South Korea d Gwangju Research Center, Korea Institute of Industrial Technology (KITECH), Gwangju 61012, South Korea Gwangju Research Center Korea Institute of Industrial Technology (KITECH) Gwangju 61012 South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author at: Chemical Energy Storage and Transformation Center (CHESS), Research Institute for Solar and Sustainable Energies (RISE), Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology (GIST), Gwangju 500–712, South Korea. at: Chemical Energy Storage and Transformation Center (CHESS), Research Institute for Solar and Sustainable Energies (RISE), Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology (GIST), Gwangju 500–712, South Korea We observe the influence of Al occupancies in Li sites on the formation process of the garnet solid electrolyte of Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO). A direct incorporation of Al is first promoted in a Li-insufficient garnet solid electrolyte during the calcination process of 850 °C and then the cubic phase of LLZO is obtained after successive annealing step of 1000 °C. Comparing to pristine LLZO, Al incorporated LLZO shows less formation of Li2CO3, keeping crystallographic and physicochemical properties. This Al incorporation improves both the ionic conductivity and interfacial resistance to poisoning procedure. Graphical abstract Al-incorporated Li-insufficient garnet solid electrolyte synthesized by modified sol-gel process and effective stabilization of cubic phase suppressing Li2CO3 formation by changing Al site preferences. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Li7La3Zr2O12 Al incorporation Garnet solid electrolyte Cubic phase 1 Introduction Any solid electrolytes with fast lithium-ion conduction have been considerable attracted as one of the key technologies for the development of next-generation energy storage systems such as all-solid-state Li batteries, Li–S battery and Li–air battery [1–5]. Various types of lithium-ion-conductive solid electrolytes have been reported, such as layered Li3N, Li14Zn(GeO4)4, Li1+x Al x Ti2- x (PO4)3 (LATP), Li3 x La(2/3)− x TiO3 (LLTO) and Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) [6]. Among them, garnet-type LLZO has been widely studied as a promising lithium-ion solid electrolyte because of its attractive value of ionic conductivity and its low grain boundary resistance [2]. Garnet-type LLZO exists in two stable crystalline tetragonal and cubic phases [7–9], which clearly have different ionic conductivities. The tetragonal phase is known as a stable structure at room temperature owing to ordered Li structures [9–11]. On the other hand, the cubic phase has disordered Li sites, which results in a much higher ionic conductivity (∼10−4 S·cm−1) than the tetragonal phase (∼10−6 S·cm−1). Therefore, a number of studies have focused on the preparation of cubic phase applying heat treatment of ca. 1200 °C [12], but its harsh heat treatment cannot avoid rapid Li evaporation. The second focus is unstable and reactive surface of cubic phase under air environment [13] and the surface formation of Li2CO3 hinders fast conduction of lithium ion. To overcome all, previous approaches have tried that several dopants could stabilize cubic phase [14–22]. Matsui et al. [10,11,18] reported that the substituted Al element occupies the Li sites, which enables the phase transformation from the tetragonal phase to the cubic phase by destabilizing the Li ordering in the tetragonal phase. Of late, Shin et al. [15] reported that Ga and Ta could successfully stabilize the cubic phase and enhance the ionic conductivity simultaneously. Trivalent dopants (e.g. Al, Ga) prefer to occupy Li sites, thus reducing the Li content of the cubic phase, which could limit ionic conductivity. The use of Al dopants as cubic-phase stabilizers by partially replacing Li sites (i.e., 24d tetrahedral, 48 g/96 h octahedral sites) have been considered [19–22]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the 24d sites are energetically more favorable for Al than the 48 g/96 g sites [23]. Because those 24d sites are joint sites of the Li-ion pathway, Al substitution would impede three-dimensional Li diffusion in the cubic phase. Hence, it is important to find the novel way to use Al as a cubic-phase stabilizer not as disrupter to block Li-ion paths. In this study, we compared LLZO with and without Al incorporation in terms of (i) cubic phase formation, (ii) improvement of ionic conductivity, and (iii) structural stability to the air exposure applying differential thermal analysis (DTA), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). 2 Experimental Al-LLZO were prepared by a modified sol-gel process using LiNO3 (Alfa Aesar), La(NO3)3·6H2O (Alfa Aesar), ZrO(NO3)2·xH2O (Sigma Aldrich), and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (Sigma Aldrich). The precursors were dissolved in distilled water according to the stoichiometric Li:La:Zr:Al molar ratio of 6.25:3:2:0.25. Additional Li (10 wt%) was added to compensate for the Li loss during high-temperature heat treatment. After complete dissolution of the precursors, citric acid and 1-butanol were added to the solution as chelating and surface active agents, respectively. The solution was gently stirred at 60 °C and after complete evaporation of all solvents, a yellowish gel was obtained. The gel was heated to 250 °C and held at that temperature for 1 h in the air. The dried powder was then heated to 700 °C and held for 6 h. The same process was conducted with intentional addition of Al precursor. The as-prepared powder was annealed in alumina crucibles at various temperatures. The synthesis procedure is depicted in Fig. 1 . Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, TGA-50H Shimadzu) and differential thermal analysis (DTA, STA PT 1000, Linseis) were carried out to investigate the thermal properties of the samples in the air with a heating rate 5 °C·min−1. The phase transformation of samples were characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku–Miniflex ІІ, Cu-Kα). The surface stability and impurity formations were identified using X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) at the 7D beamline and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) at the 8A2 beamline of the Pohang Light Source (PLS). Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, S-4700, Hitachi) was utilized to observe the cross-section and particle morphology of samples. An inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS, Nexion 300X, PerkinElmer) was used to determine the Li and Al content of the samples. For AC electrochemical measurements, samples are placed onto the pellet with a diameter of 12 mm. As-prepared powders were thoroughly mixed in an agate mortar with the addition of 2 wt% lithium borate (Li3BO3) to improve interfacial contact and pressed into pellets using a hydraulic press at 12 MPa [24]. The average thickness of the pressed pellets was approximately 0.9 mm. The processed pellets were sintered in alumina crucibles at 1000 °C up to 20 h buried in the mother powder to minimize the loss of Li. The ionic conductivity of the sintered pellets is measured using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS, Zahner Elecktrik GmbH & Co.) in the frequency range of 0.1 Hz to 3 MHz from 15 °C to 100 °C with an amplitude of 100 mV. For the EIS experiments, Au paste was used as an ion blocking electrodes and Li metal foils were attached to investigate the interface stability between the electrolyte and the electrode. Impedances and ionic conductivities of the prepared cells were calculated from the Nyquist plots and the equation σ = ( 1 Z ) ( L A ) , where σ is ionic conductivity, Z is the impedance, L is the thickness of the pellet, and A is the area of the pellet. The activation energy was also determined from the ionic conductivity as a function of temperature data using the Arrhenius equation. 3 Results and discussion The highly conductive cubic phase have reported that Al dopants play a key role as cubic-phase stabilizers by replacing lithium lattice sites (e.g. 24d, 48 g, and 96 h) [10,11,14,18,23,25]. Although the exact Al sites replacing Li sites are not experimentally clear, it seems quite certain that Al substitution could produce a stabilized cubic phase and provide fast Li-ion conduction. To maximize the Al doping effect, we controlled the Li amount of the starting materials to 6.25 mol per formula unit (p.f.u.) with 10 wt% additional Li rather than to the conventional amount of 7 mol p.f.u, since the actual Li concentration of the synthesized LLZO was lower than intended [11,18]. This demonstrates that it is not easy to control the Li content during the long and high-temperature synthetic process because of Li evaporation and it might have an advantage of initial low content of Li to lead direct Al-incorporation reaction. To investigate influences of direct Al-incorporation on low Li content samples, we conducted differential thermal analysis (DTA) with calcined samples of Al-Li6.875La3Zr2O12 (Al-LLZO), pristine Li6.875La3Zr2O12 (p-LLZO), and standard Li7La3Zr2O12 (s-LLZO). The endothermic peak in Fig. 2 (a) for s-LLZO at 640 °C is attributed to the phase transition from tetragonal to cubic [10]. Endothermic peaks for both Al-LLZO and p-LLZO were observed at a higher temperature of 665 °C. The differences between p-LLZO and Li-insufficient samples were attributed to low Li content. The deficiency of Li sites might cause the phase transition from tetragonal to cubic phase. Another endothermic peak was observed at approximately 850 °C and we assumed that the peak was due to the reaction incorporating Al into the cubic structure. Matsui et al. reported that the impurity phase in tetragonal Li-insufficient LLZO disappeared above 850 °C [10] and thus, the peak at 850 °C seems to provide evidence of the Al incorporation reaction. Fig. 3 shows XRD pattern of Al-LLZO and p-LLZO calcined for 6 h at 800 °C, 900 °C, and 1000 °C applying a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1. Separated images in Fig. 3 indicate the formation progress of cubic phase of (422) peak with increasing temperature and distinct cubic phase clearly appeared at 1000 °C that is relatively lower one compared to the temperature used in previous study [2]. This could be attributed to slow dry process of sol-gel that enables to reactive pre-formation of LaZr compound [6,12,17,24]. The (422) is peak resulted from the merge of the tetragonal phase (422) and (224) peaks. The (224) peak of the tetragonal phase began to appear at approximately 800 °C and merged with (442) at 900 °C. With Al-LLZO, merging and shifting of peaks happen together. On the other hand, p-LLZO shows that merging of two peaks first observed and then the merged peak shifted into cubic phase. To be more specific, we performed Rietveld refinement of Al-LLZO and p-LLZO after sintering at 1000 °C. We used FullProf suite program and results were shown in Fig. 4 and Brag R factors were 9.81% for Al-LLZO and 9.77% for p-LLZO, respectively. After sintering, both structures were cubic, space group Ia-3d with several impurity phases. Both pellets maintained a cubic phase, but several impurities were formed after the sintering process. The La2ZrO7 phase was identified in both pellets, and this phase is attributed to the Li deficiency [26]. A small amount of LaAlO3 was detected from p-LLZO pellet. Tetragonal phase peaks were also observed at approximately 57° and 59° in the XRD pattern of the Li7- y La3Zr2O12, indicating that the cubic phase became unstable owing to the loss of Li during the sintering process at 1000 °C [11]. However Al-LLZO retained a solid cubic phase except for the formation of La2Zr2O7 [26], since Shinawi et al. reported that several secondary phases can act as cubic-phase stabilizers to improve Li-ion conductivity [23]. With the same point of view, Al incorporation might have influenced the structural formation of secondary phases in the samples. The refined lattice parameters were a = 12.975 (1) for Al-LLZO and increased a = 12.991 (1) for p-LLZO. Occupied Li sites by Al were still unclear, however, they showed different Al dopant in Li sites. p-LLZO shows increased Al occupancy in 24d Li sites than Al- LLZO (see Fig. 4). This means that the Al occupancy in 24d Li sites could be controlled by Al doping method. We think that the presence of Al in the sample resulted in a different rate of cubic-phase formation. The presence of Al precursors in the sample appears to delay the cubic-phase modification and less occupy 24d Li sites than Al from the alumina crucible. Their cross-sectional SEM images is presented in Fig. 5 (a), (b), (d), and (e) and the grain sizes ranged from a few microns to approximately 10 μm. We expected that the small number of grain boundaries would reduce the interfacial resistance between the electrolyte and the electrode. However, there were no distinct differences between Al-LLZO and p-LLZO. EDS of the bulk of the pellet are shown in Fig. 5(c) and (f). The cross-sectional surface also shows a different existence of the Al phase between the Al-LLZO and p-LLZO grains. EDS data shows Al-LLZO of 1.02 at% Al and p-LLZO of 0.08 at% of Al. Fig. 6 is a schematic illustration of (a) cubic garnet Al-Li7- x La3Zr2O12 and (b) Li-Li sites distribution of each sample. The Li ion conduction in the cubic phase is promoted by two major phenomena. The restricted and occupied interatomic separation of Li and the unstable Li ions caused by local Li-Li repulsion [15]. Fig. 6(b) shows the shorter Li (96 h)-Li (96 h) and Li (96 h)-Li (24d) bond distances of Al-LLZO compared to those of p-LLZO. The shorter bond lengths are crucial to lower the activation energy for the Li-ion transportation, even though the length difference is quite small. We measured the electrochemical impedance to investigate the ionic conductivities of Al-LLZO and p-LLZO. Before the impedance measurements, all pellets were polished using diamond sandpapers in an Ar gas-filled glove box to remove contamination from the surface. A simple equivalent circuit of (R s)(R bulk//Q bulk)(R gb//Q gb) (see inset image in Fig. 7 ) was used to fit the Nyquist plot of the samples, shown in Fig. 7. The impedance plots using Au electrodes showed typical semicircles at high frequencies with tails at low frequencies. Al-LLZO showed lower bulk and grain boundary resistance values (R bulk = 682.4 Ω, R gb = 65.6 Ω) than that p-LLZO (R bulk = 745.4 Ω, R gb = 88.2 Ω) and it resulted from the effect of impurity phases on the properties of p-LLZO. Arrhenius plot of Al-LLZO was illustrated based on impedance data with different operation temperature (Fig. 8 a). We obtained an ionic conductivity of 5.1 × 10−4 S·cm−1 and 9.9 × 10−5 S·cm−1 at 60 °C and 25 °C, respectively and its activation energy is 0.36 eV (Fig. 8b). To investigate the surface stability of Al-LLZO and p-LLZO, XPS was carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 9 (a). The XPS spectra of C 1 s, Li 1 s, O 1 s, La 4d, and Zr 3d detected the formation of Li2CO3 on the surfaces. The peak at approximately 291 eV is assigned to carbonate. The peak at approximately 55.4 eV is attributed to Li2CO3, and the peak at 54.2 eV is due to the LiO bond of LLZO. Signals from the peaks of La 4d and Zr 3d were not detected because of the scattering depth limitation of XPS in inorganic materials [13,27]. Comparing with the intensity of Li2CO3 peaks in all samples, Al-LLZO showed less value and it means that Li2CO3 formation was deterred on Al-LLZO. Fig. 9(b) shows the normalized O K-edge spectra of Al-LLZO and p-LLZO. A major absorption peak was observed at approximately 534.5 eV, known as the O 1 s π* transition (C = O), on both samples [13]. This peak suggests that Li2CO3 formed on the both samples. However, only Al-Li7− x La3Zr2O12 showed another peak at 533 eV, assigned to O 1 s from LLZO, at the same time. The operation mode of XAS was limited to an approximately 10 nm depth profile and it means that Al-LLZO partially has LLZO surface not totally covered by surface formed Li2CO3. It is in excellent agreement with above XPS results. Li-insufficient phases containing Al would be an effective way to form the more stable cubic phase. 4 Conclusions As a result, we confirmed that Al incorporation into Li-insufficient garnet not only stabilized the cubic phase for high ionic conductivity, but also enhanced the surface and interfacial properties by limiting Li2CO3 formation. We could summarize the Al incorporation is the way to avoid blocking Li pathway of 24d and enhance higher ionic conductivity with simple modification. Further study should be investigated to understand exact mechanism forming Li2CO3 on the Al doped Li-insufficient garnet electrolytes. coredata.dc:description: We observe the influence of Al occupancies in Li sites on the formation process of the garnet solid electrolyte of Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO). A direct incorporation of Al is first promoted in a Li-insufficient garnet solid electrolyte during the calcination process of 850 °C and then the cubic phase of LLZO is obtained after successive annealing step of 1000 °C. Comparing to pristine LLZO, Al incorporated LLZO shows less formation of Li2CO3, keeping crystallographic and physicochemical properties. This Al incorporation improves both the ionic conductivity and interfacial resistance to poisoning procedure.

coredata.dc:title: Al-incorporation into Li7La3Zr2O12 solid electrolyte keeping stabilized cubic phase for all-solid-state Li batteries
